revealed_symptoms.ulceration: It’s like a cut or sore that just won’t heal, and sometimes it scabs over but comes right back.
revealed_symptoms.border irregularity: The edges are all jagged, kinda messy, not smooth like my other moles.
revealed_symptoms.satellite lesions: There are these little dots or spots popping up near the main one, like it’s spreading.
revealed_symptoms.induration: It feels thicker or harder than the rest of my skin, like there's something under there.
revealed_symptoms.asymmetry: One side of this mole looks different from the other, like it's lopsided or uneven.
revealed_symptoms.spontaneous bleeding: Sometimes this spot just starts bleeding out of nowhere, even if I don’t touch it.

hidden_symptoms.diameter >6mm: It’s bigger than the eraser on a pencil, and I feel like it’s still growing.
hidden_symptoms.color variation: It’s got a bunch of different colors—like brown, black, maybe even some red or blue mixed in.
hidden_symptoms.evolving: This thing keeps changing—getting darker, bigger, or just looking different than before.
hidden_symptoms.erythema: The skin around it looks red or puffy, like it’s irritated or reacting to something.
hidden_symptoms.shiny or waxy bump: It looks kinda like a smooth, shiny pimple, but it never pops or goes away.
hidden_symptoms.telangiectasia: There are these tiny, spidery red blood vessels around the spot that I didn’t notice before.

patient_history.content: Hi, I'll be your doctor today. What brings you in?

Well, I have this spot that's been acting up. It's like a cut or sore that just won’t heal, and sometimes it scabs over but comes right back. The edges are all jagged, kinda messy, not smooth like my other moles. There are these little dots or spots popping up near the main one, like it’s spreading. It feels thicker or harder than the rest of my skin, like there's something under there. One side of this mole looks different from the other, like it's lopsided or uneven. And sometimes this spot just starts bleeding out of nowhere, even if I don’t touch it.

Thank you for providing the information. I understand that you have a non-healing sore that has irregular edges and sometimes bleeds. To help me understand this better, has this spot been itching, or is it painful?
No, it hasn't been itching, and it's not really painful either. Just… there.
Thanks for clarifying that it's not itchy or painful. Has the size, color, or the way the spot feels changed at all over time?

Yes, I feel like it's still growing. It's got a bunch of different colors—like brown, black, maybe even some red or blue mixed in. It keeps changing—getting darker, bigger, or just looking different than before.

Thank you. The changes you are describing, including the growth and the different colors, are concerning. Based on the information you've provided, I am concerned about the possibility of skin cancer. Further evaluation is needed, and you may need to see a dermatologist for a biopsy to confirm the diagnosis. Does this information align with your concerns?
I don’t really know what that means. Can you tell me more about a biopsy?

Of course. A biopsy is a procedure where a small sample of the affected skin is removed and sent to a lab. The lab will examine the sample under a microscope to see if cancer cells are present and determine the type of cancer, if any. This is important to get the right diagnosis and plan for treatment. It is typically a quick procedure and can be done in your doctor's office. Does that help?
Yes, that helps. So, they take a tiny piece and look at it?

Yes, exactly. They take a very small piece of the concerning area and examine it under a microscope to look for any abnormal cells, including cancer cells. This helps to confirm the diagnosis and determine the best course of action. Do you have any other questions about the biopsy?
No, I don’t think so. So, what happens next?

The edges are all jagged, kinda messy, not smooth like my other moles. There are these little dots or spots popping up near the main one, like it’s spreading.
